title.narrative: Facilitating the Reintegration of women and girls as survivors of sexual violence by Boko Haram and Reconciliation of communities affected by Boko Haram in Northeast Nigeria

description.narrative:
As a result of the insurgency in North East Nigeria, communities have suffered loss, trauma and divisions. Communities have been divided along religious, ethnic, linguistic, geographic lines and these divisions have also split families, with several cases of siblings from the same household joining conflicting groups including the army, the Civilian Joint Task Force (CJTF) and Boko Haram.
The programme aims to contribute to sustainable peace and stability in North East Nigeria through increasing the resilience of communities affected by violent conflict. There is one overall project Theory of Change: If stigma-reduction activities and awareness-raising efforts are increased AND social cohesion activities are provided to community members THEN reintegration of women and girls associated with Boko Haram and children born of sexual violence by Boko Haram will be improved and communities will be prepared to accept women, girls and their children into the social fabric THEREBY making individuals and communities more resilient to the negative impacts of protracted violent conflict.
The objectives of this Programme Cooperation Agreement (PCA) are in line with Federal Government of Nigeria and UNICEFâ€™s Rolling Work Plan for Child Protection 2015-2016 â€“ Enhance Protection and Response for Children Affected by Armed Conflict under Output 36 - and will contribute to the current UNICEF Nigeria Country Programme (2014-2017) child protection outcome.

Direct Beneficiaries (760): 400 women and girls through 2.1 support sessions (75% under 18 years old; 25% over 18 years old); 200 women and girls through 2.2 small scale initiatives (SSI) (at least 50% of 400 support session participants would participate directly in SSI) (these are counted under the group above); 360 family members through 3.1 support sessions; 400 community members through 4.1 community dialogues (at least 15% women over 18 and 15% young men under the age of 18 to participate). Indirect Beneficiaries (246; defined as those that are supporting the reintegration of women and girls and children born of sexual violence)

Impact: Greater social cohesion and resilience to violent conflict and violent extremism in North East Nigeria through increased awareness for conflict survivors and advocacy for community healing
Outcome: Stronger relationships within and between communities in target areas lead to stronger social cohesion

Output 1 (Cross Cutting Capacity Building for local actors in 10 locations): Increased capacity of influential people in 10 locations to engage in community dialogue to reduce stigma and increase awareness and understanding at the community level Output 2 (Individual-Level support): Vulnerability of women and girls after incidents of violence by armed actors (state and non-state actors) is reduced and chances of successful reintegration increased Output 3 (Family-Level support): Families of returnees who have suffered Boko Haram related sexual violence accept and support their wives/daughters/relatives, as well as children born out of conflict related violence Output 4 (Community Level of Support): Target communities have increased capacities to manage their interaction with and understanding of survivors of sexual violence and the children born of sexual violence by Boko Haram; thereby building a protective environment for women and girls and children born of sexual violence
